In order to deliver high and safe standards of service, it is necessary to ensure all systems, plans and processes are formally documented and audited for compliance purposes.

As the Estates and Facilities Management (EFM) Directorate moves into a single entity across MSB, modernisation and improvement is a key objective to support the Trust to meet its' objectives. This will involve some changes to current business functions including, but not limited to, robust record management and policies and procedures.

The purpose of this document is to outline a formal process to be followed when developing and proceeding to implement a strategy, policy, procedure and processes (such as working instructions and guidelines).

This procedure provides a framework for all authors that clarify all the essential components irrespective of subject matter and an approval and ratification process that is objective, appropriate and robust.
The main aims are to ensure that all processes within EFM Directorate are:
Consistently accurate and clearly documented;
Meeting governance and recording any statutory and legislative requirements;
Providing EFM staff with clear guidance where applicable;
Presented in a standardised, corporate and professional standard;
Subject to a complete audit trail from authorship to Trust ratification via appropriate consultation to satisfy the requirements of internal and external auditors.
This procedure applies to all documents that contain an element of required action by the EFM Directorate or by individual staff within the directorate.
The following definitions are used within this document.

data.text: EFM Board has responsibility for approving all EFM Policies, Strategies (Tier 1) and Procedures (Tier 2) before they are submitted to the Corporate and site ratification control groups for final ratification.
EFM Business Development Unit is responsible for checking that all EFM policy and procedure documents have:
Appropriate authorship;
Appropriate consultation;
Professional/technical approval and has been approved for ratification by the appropriate group;
Implementation plan, including documented procedures where necessary.

Asset Owner is deemed the Professional Approver who is responsible for approving a document. Approval provides a statement of assurance to the Trust Board that the document is technically/professionally/legally correct, that the consultation process has been appropriate and that the resources are available such that the requirements of the policy can be met.
5.3.1  The Asset Owner is also responsible for ensuring:
Asset Author is assigned;
Policy is compliant;
Policy is accurate and reviewed accordingly as a result of changes to legislation or practice;
Policy is implemented effectively;

Records of all approved documents Tier 3 and 4 (refer to point 6.1) are filed locally and that the location of these documents is known widely within a department in order that they can be accessed irrespective of whether their usual “carer” is present in case they are needed for Freedom of Information or legal purposes.
Asset Author is responsible for ensuring that the:
Document is development or reviewed in accordance with the Asset Owners instructions;
Document checklists are utilised; (Refer to Appendix C)
Relevant key stakeholders are engaged with developing or reviewing the document;
Records of the consultation are filed.

Document Controller is the designated officer within the EFM Business Development Unit that is responsible for checking that all EFM policy and procedure documents have the following prior to submitting to the Trust corporate document ratification and control groups:
Appropriate authorship;
Appropriate consultation;
Professional/technical approval and has been approved for ratification by the appropriate group;
Implementation plan, including documented procedures where necessary.
In addition, they will:
Maintaining the documentation register and regulate changes with version control;
Ensure Tier 1 and 2 (refer to point 6.1) documents are adequately protected against unauthorised alteration.
EFM Service Manager is responsible for ensuring that:
Robust and suitable filing system is in place to enable easy access to local documents;
Documents locally filed are accessible to all relevant staff – electronic and hard copied and that any confidential documents are restricted as necessary;
Working Instructions (Tier 3) are filed in the EFM Management Hub - service folders.

data.text: Document Presentation and Guidelines
Each document should be developed in accordance with Trust presentation standards and must be presented using the corporate templates to ensure consistency and corporate standards.
Document Generation, Review and Control
Guidelines for creating and update documents is summarised in Appendix B.
6.3.1 Generating a Document

Each document must have an Asset Owner – this is the person responsible for ensuring that the correct document template is used, that the document is passed for ratification accordingly and that document is reviewed within the timescale documented at the time of ratification.
6.3.2 Document Content
Documents should be easy to follow and relevant to the subject matter. They must be in accordance with other relevant Trust documents and meet any relevant statutory and legislation requirements.
Any legislation relevant to the document content must be referenced in Tier 1 document and the relevant Tier 2 document should also be referenced
Guidance on content of documents can be seen in Appendix B. To ensure all documents meet requirements, a checklist for authors can be seen at Appendix C.
6.3.3 Consultation and Feedback

All key stakeholders that either input into the document or are affected should be involved through consultation. This should include representation from non- managerial staff. Once drafted, the document should be issued for comment and feedback.
For example, where a procedure involves something a porter is responsible for, a porter as well as the Portering Manager should be deemed a key stakeholder and included in the consultation.

Consultation period should be realistic with a minimum of 2 weeks provided for feedback. Failure to meet this deadline may result in comments not being accepted unless there is a justifiable reason for the delay. Records of the consultation should be kept by the Asset Author.
EFM Site Managers and relevant EFM Heads of Services should be included in all consultation.
6.3.4 Approval Process

When all valid comments have been included, the final document should be sent to the relevant leads and committees as outlined below before being submitted to the Business Development Unit for ratification purposes and maintain central documentation registers and local site hub links. The flow chart to summarise the approval and ratification process is outlined in Appendix A.

data.text: 6.3.5 Communications and Implementation
It is an essential requirement that approved documents are cascaded and implemented and the plans for communicating and implementing will form part of any Tier 1 and 2 documents.

The Asset Owner will be responsible for ensuring that the new or updated/amended document are communicated appropriately to EFM Service Managers. It is then the EFM Service Managers responsibility to further cascade.

Following cascade of the document it is the responsibility of local area management to ensure that the document is implemented in a timely manner this can be done via e- mail, tool box talk, com cells, meetings or via 1:1s.
6.3.6 EFM Document Register
The EFM Document Register is held and managed by the Business Development Unit. All Tier 1 and Tier 2 documents must have an EFM Document Register number which is provided by the Document Controller.

The EFM Document Register records the details from the front pages of the documents and is colour coded as seen below in order to track the compliance of documents in date. This register can be seen on the EFM Management Information Hub by EFM Management Team.
Green - current policy and within date;
Red - non- compliant policy and out of date;
High Amber - review of policy due in next month;
Low Amber - review of policy due in next 3 months;
Purple Review – review policy due in next 6 months.
6.3.7 Version Control

All document history must recorded on the document. In principle, each document will be numbered in accordance with the Trust's Document Provenance Policy (08042) where a trust reference number will be allocated following ratification at the Trust or MSB Document Ratification Group for Tier 1 and Tier 2 documents.
Where an author revises a policy, the document review history must be completed.
The exception to this rule is when there are minor amendments required to a document not amounting to “a revision” and is required whilst a document remains current.
6.3.8 Reviewing and Amending

No document should have a review period of more than 3 years. All Tier 1 and 2 documents will be held on the EFM Documentation Register and monitored by the Document Controller to ensure that they are reviewed within timescale. The Asset Owner will be alerted 3 months prior to the document review date – it is then the responsibility of the Asset Owner to assign a Asset Author for review and update.
6.3.9 Formal Review

When a document is due for formal review, i.e. following the 3 years or alternative allocated review period, the document must be consultated on as a new document following the process from section 6.3.1.

Document reviews shall also occur when the document becomes no longer valid, changes in work practices occur, changes in legislation or guidance affecting the document, in the case of an incident or dangerous occurrence, or where shortfalls are identified by management or by internal audit.
Accessing Ratified Documents
All EFM ratified documents should be filed and made accessible as outlined below.
Tier 1 and 2 (Policies and Procedures) - Site EFM Information Hub and site Staffnet/Intranet ;
Tier 3 (Working Instructions) - Site EFM Information Hub / Service Folders.
Archiving Documents

A copy of all approved Tier 1 and 2 documents will be held by the Document Controller. It is the Asset Owners' responsibility to keep a record of all approved versions of Tier 3 and 4. The security of all retained documents is essential irrespective of whether they are kept manually or electronically.

It is also the responsibility of the Asset Owner to ensure that the location of these documents is known widely within a department in order that they can be accessed irrespective of whether their usual “carer” is present in case they are needed for Freedom of Information or legal purposes.
Records should be managed in line with the Corporate Document and Records Management Policy (NHS England) and Records Management Code of Practice for Health and Social Care  Documents must be:
Available for retrieval and suitable for use;
Changed in conjunction with version control;
Adequately protected against unauthorised alteration;
Disposed of in line with the Trust retention schedules.
8.1.2  All documents should be Identifiable, appropriately stored to protect them, protected to preserve them from loss or deterioration, retrievable and have an appropriate retention schedule.
General Records

8.2.1 All documents that contain sensitive information must be stored securely and only accessible to essential users. (e.g. paper records locked in filing cabinets and electronic records stored in the appropriate departmental secure drive).

8.2.2 All documents are to be protected from deterioration in an appropriate manner for hard copies the storage method needs to include protection from moisture or any environmental aspects, electronic records need to be backed-up in the case of unexpected system failure.

8.2.3 All documents that have exceeded the retention date need to be reviewed and archived or disposed of in the appropriate manner as described in the Records Management code of practice for health and social care.
Paper Records

8.3.1 Complex filing regimes where required must have a register which should contain a description, the opening date and also a unique identification code. Where these are not required the person responsible for the filing should ensure that the records are retrievable and the retention period made known.
8.3.2 The register should also include information on the year in which non-archival records are due for destruction.
8.3.3 The movement and location of records should be controlled to ensure that a record can be easily retrieved at any time and there is an audit trail of record transactions.
8.3.4 Records are to be stored locally by local service managers.
Electronic Records Management
8.4.1 The EFM Document Controller is responsible for the management of Tier 1 and Tier 2 documents.

8.4.2 Where records are kept on an electronic filing system it should be on the EFM drive to ensure that all systems are being regularly backed up by the IT Department. Records should not be saved on desktops as there is no back-up of individual computers.
8.4.3 Records should be kept in a legible, neat and orderly way with such information entered as required, to allow availability to those who may require the records.

Adherence to EFM policies and procedure and document control will be tested as part of the EFM internal assurance process as shown in the diagram below and outlind in the EFM Assurance Policy. Results of policy audits will be submitted to the EFM Board and subsequent actions plans where necessary.
Compliance of all EFM Policies and Procedures will included in EFM Performance Dashboard presented at the MSB EFM Board to highlight and monitor where Tier 1 and 2 documents are out of date.

Appendix B
Guide to Producing a Procedure

data.url: MSEPO-19006 Estates and Facilities Management for Document Control 1.2.026.png

data.text: The best way to approach writing a policy or strategy is to first:
“Brainstorm” all the elements that need to be somewhere in the document without worrying about whether they are in the right order at this stage;
Draft just the main headings of the Contents Page;
Now add the subheadings that will be needed under each main heading;
Check that all the elements of the brainstorm are going to fit in somewhere;
Start filling out the headings (in any order) and tick off the brainstorm list as
each element is covered.
The principles about the content are the same for both Policies and Procedures but there should be more detail within a procedure as to the processes in place.

Write every EFM Procedure document as if you are writing for a junior staff member in their first week, alone on a shift at 2am. These should be written from the perspective that someone who is unfamiliar with it may require the key information quickly, no rambling or repetition.

table_items.text: Overview of why it exists. Keep detailed references to legal frameworks or Acts of Parliament to a minimum – you will be listing them in the references, just include the main drivers here.
The specific targets that the document is setting out to meet. Look at the first 2 paragraphs of this policy as an example. The aims should be auditable.
Who is it aimed at or what does this document cover and most importantly who or what is excluded.
Consider whether an explanatory section of terms used would be helpful to the readership but this is not essential.

Who has ultimate responsibility? Is the day to day management devolved? What are the roles for each staff group. This section may not be necessary for small or minor documents. For Policy documents (Tier 1) keep the content of this section high level, the details should be in the linked procedure document (Tier 2).
Complete the Preliminary Equality Impact Assessment (EIA) to determine if a full assessment is required. Add statement …“the EFM directorate is committed to the
provision of a service that is fair accessible and meets the needs of all individuals”. See Appendix D for Preliminary/Full EIA.”

Now start on the content, there may be many paragraphs or just a few. The most important thing to remember is “logical sequence” Where there are forms applicable to the document these must be included as appendices.
Provide details of training requirements for staff involved in the delivery of the procedure where applicable.

How will you know that it's been followed? Consider the following: What the key standards of the document are; How these could be monitored e.g. formal audit, quarterly spot checks, review of reported incidents and complaints, patient or staff surveys, sickness levels, training records; Who will be responsible for this and how often will the process be done; Which forum should review the findings; Who will be responsible for implementing any required actions.

List all the references that have been sourced particularly important are Acts of Parliament, Codes of Practice etc. and any legislative references. The Libraries at Mid, Southend and Basildon can support your search for evidence and advise on the correct way to set out your references.

If there are forms attached or other directional detail such as flowcharts, guidance then these must be attached as complete documents and should not be embedded. Reference material such as DoH guidance should not be embedded – use links where feasible - use web links if reference documents are on-line.

data.text: A working instruction contains much more detail than a procedure and should be created wherer specific and detailed intructions are required.
A working instruction is the most detailed description of a task. The sole purpose of a work instruction is to explain step by step how to do a specific task.
A working instruction should be easy to follow and succinct. Flowcharts and process maps are particularly benefical for outlining a process or tasks. Screen shot and photos can also be beneficial.

data.text: Before submitting a document for consideration, please ensure that you have included and checked the following:

table_items.text: Does the document clearly define what the purpose of the document is for? Have you included who the document relates to?
Policy (Tier 1) – which legislation, statutory requirements or NHS guidance does this relate to? Procedures (Tier 2) – which policy does this document relate to?
Have you assessed for the need to include an Equality Impact Assessment? There should still be an Equality & Diversity statement within the document.

Have all necessary training requirements been considered to successfully deliver the outcome of this document on a continual basis? Think about whether any special training would be required, how it would be delivered and recorded.

Style - Tier 1 and 2 documents - have you followed the Trust template provided, using same formatting and font? Ensure cover pages are completed. Spelling – have you done a spell check and proof read.
Have all key stakeholders been consulted with?
What group should the document be presented at before going to EFM Board (Tier 1 and 2)? Has the EFM Service Manager approved the document before implementing (Tier 3)?
Is there a plan to implement this document and who is leading on this? Is it clear how the owner/author will communicate this document to the appropriate staff groups?

Who will monitor the adherence to the document and where will the outcomes be reported and discussed, e.g. what will be the evidence that this policy or guideline has been followed, and to whom will audits be reported and how often?
Have you asked a colleague to read the document – does it flow and make sense to them? It should tell a story.
